This passage from Surah An-Naml discusses the contrasting behaviors of those who believe in Allah and those who do not. It highlights how people's actions can be influenced by their faith or disbelief. When in distress, those who associate partners with Allah call upon Allah in His Mercy, showing their natural inclination towards Allah when facing difficulties. However, the instant they are saved, they begin to associate partners with Allah again, which is an expression of the excessive pride (khushu' in Arabic) one has against accepting that the universe is under the control of a single Creator and that His power is absolute. Surah An-Naml asserts that it is disbelief in Allah that is ultimately met with recompense, where those who associate partners with Allah will be met with a place in Hell (Mithw) due to their disobedience and disbelief. It also reminds the believers of their role in seeking Allah's guidance and ensuring they are always with good deeds, reminding them of the importance of being guided by Allah’s teachings and being supported by His mercy.
